verses.text: Then Moses and the elders of Israel commanded the people, saying, “Keep all the commandments that I am commanding you today.”
verses.comment: Reflects the command for ongoing obedience to all the law's commands.

verses.text: And on the day you cross over the Jordan into the land that the LORD your God is giving you, you shall set up for yourself large stones and cover them with plaster.
verses.comment: The verb 'cover with plaster' reflects a typical ancient Near Eastern method for inscriptions.

verses.text: You shall write on them all the words of this law, when you cross over, so that you may enter the land that the LORD your God is giving you, a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the LORD, the God of your fathers, has promised you.
verses.comment: The phrase 'all the words of this law' refers to the law code as given to Moses.

verses.text: When you have crossed over the Jordan, you shall set up these stones on Mount Ebal, as I command you today, and you shall cover them with plaster.
verses.comment: Mount Ebal is specified as the site for this stone monument.

verses.text: And there you shall build an altar to the LORD your God, an altar of stones. You shall not wield an iron tool on them.
verses.comment: Maintains the prohibition of using iron tools, for ritual purity.

verses.text: You shall build the altar of the LORD your God with uncut stones; and you shall offer burnt offerings on it to the LORD your God.
verses.comment: "Uncut stones" closely follows the Hebrew term for stones not shaped by tools.

verses.text: And you shall sacrifice peace offerings and eat there, and rejoice before the LORD your God.
verses.comment: 'Rejoice' reflects the Hebrew sense of covenant celebration.

verses.text: And you shall write very clearly all the words of this law on the stones.
verses.comment: 'Very clearly' (Hebrew: 'well explained') emphasizes legibility and accuracy.

verses.text: Then Moses and the Levitical priests said to all Israel, “Be silent and listen, O Israel: This day you have become the people of the LORD your God.”
verses.comment: Ceremonial declaration of Israel’s special status.

verses.text: Therefore you shall obey the voice of the LORD your God, and keep his commandments and his statutes that I am commanding you today.”
verses.comment: The phrase 'the voice' means to heed God's commands.

verses.text: That day Moses commanded the people, saying,
verses.comment: Serves as a transition to the instructions for the blessings and curses.

verses.text: “When you have crossed over the Jordan, these shall stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin.
verses.comment: Lists tribal representatives to bless from Mount Gerizim.

verses.text: And these shall stand on Mount Ebal for the curse: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali.
verses.comment: Tribal division for declaring the curses.

verses.text: And the Levites shall declare in a loud voice to all the men of Israel:
verses.comment: 'All the men of Israel' means all the people of Israel, as in Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: “Cursed is the man who makes a carved or cast image, an abomination to the LORD, the work of the hands of a craftsman, and sets it up in secret.” And all the people shall answer and say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: 'In secret' underscores the hidden sin of idolatry.

verses.text: “Cursed is the one who dishonors his father or his mother.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: Reflects the seriousness of honoring parents in Mosaic law.

verses.text: “Cursed is the one who moves his neighbor’s boundary marker.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: Theft of land condemned by law and community.

verses.text: “Cursed is he who leads the blind astray on the road.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: 'Leads astray' means causing harm or tricking the vulnerable.

verses.text: “Cursed is he who perverts the justice due to the sojourner, the fatherless, and the widow.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: 'Sojourner' is a close translation of the Hebrew 'ger,' meaning a foreign resident.

verses.text: “Cursed is he who lies with his father’s wife, because he has uncovered his father’s skirt.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: 'Uncovered his father’s skirt' is a Hebrew idiom for a sexual relationship.

verses.text: “Cursed is he who lies with any kind of animal.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: Prohibition of bestiality.

verses.text: “Cursed is he who lies with his sister, the daughter of his father or the daughter of his mother.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: Prohibits incest with a sister, half-sister or full.

verses.text: “Cursed is he who lies with his mother-in-law.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: Prohibits sexual relations with a mother-in-law.

verses.text: “Cursed is he who attacks his neighbor in secret.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: 'In secret' implies ambush, murder, or violence not publicly witnessed.

verses.text: “Cursed is he who takes a bribe to kill an innocent person.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: 'To kill an innocent person' is a literal rendering of the Hebrew.

verses.text: “Cursed is everyone who does not uphold the words of this law by doing them.” And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
verses.comment: Summarizes the curses for disobedience to the law. Paul references this in Galatians 3:10.
